comments:
Attached are the patch and other files required to build Eclipse 3.3M4 on s390/s390x. A brief description of the procedure i used to build the Eclipse3.3M4 on s390/s390x from its source and the attached files is following.

The files included are

1)run-patch --> It creates the build directory , by unzipping the source files ,copying the missing files required for the s390/s390x architecture, expanding the launchersrc.zip in its right place and then patching the files with the diff.patch, to create a build directory

2)run-build-->Compile the shared libraries, then start the build.

3)diff.patch-->The diff file between the final patched files and the directory created by unzipping the source files ,copying the missing files required for the s390/s390x architecture and expanding the launchersrc.zip in its right place.



To build on s390/s390x

	1)In a directory place the eclipse-sourceBuild-srcIncluded-3.3M4.zip,launchersrc.zip,diff.patch,run-patch,run-build

	2)run 		-->./run-patch 

	3)run		-->./run-build   

				or

			    cd build3.3M4

			    cd plugins/org.eclipse.core.filesystem/natives/unix/linux

			    make	

			    cd  ../../../../					  

     			    build -os linux -ws gtk -arch <arch> -compilelibs -java5home /opt/ibm-java2-<arch>-50 -target <build target>

	

arch -In my case were either s390 or s390x

It creates the build directory , by unzipping the source files ,copying the missing files required for the s390/s390x architecture, expanding the launchersrc.zip in its right place and then patching the files with the diff.patch, to create a build directory

The diff file between the final patched files and the directory created by unzipping the source files ,copying the missing files required for the s390/s390x architecture and expanding the launchersrc.zip in its right place.

A simple script i used to execute the build,not essential

Compile the shared libraries, then start the build.

I reviewed your patches and I have a couple of questions.

You are asking for two additional swt fragments.
org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.s390
org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.s390x

So the main difference between these two fragments is that s390 is 32 bit s390x is 64 bit?  If these fragments are created, are you willing to maintain the code in these fragments?

You are asking for a
core.filesystem.linux.s390
core.filesystem.linux.s390x

You to let you know, these are optional fragments.  If there isn't a filesystem fragment, they will use the default.  

Is there different code in the core.filesystem fragments than the default ones for linux?

1) 
a) Yes we propose 2 swt fragments 



 org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.s390 	--->31 bit 

 org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.s390x 	--->64 bit 



b)We would be very grateful if you can arrange with the SWT team for these to be created.

c)Yes i would take up the maintenance of the swt fragments.



2)  
a)  No the filesystem fragments   

	core.filesystem.linux.s390

	core.filesystem.linux.s390x

do not have any new code in them.

 

To be exact the code in 

core.filesystem.linux.s390 is exactly same as in core.filesystem.linux.x86 

and the code  

core.filesystem.linux.s390x is exactly same as in core.filesystem.linux.x86_64.



If you think these fragments have different/optimized code for the individual platforms then two new filesystem fragments maybe useful otherwise the default would work fine

Uttaran,

I'm in the process of of adding the support to the source scripts.  

We need to identify the osgi arch value for s390x, something that is defined in our swt fragment.

Tom Watson (equinox team says)

OSGi defines the s390 (31 bit) value to be "s390".  OSGi does not currently define s390x (64bit).  I will open a bug against osgi to get an answer.  Some of this will depend on what the java system properties are when running on the platform.  For example, what is the value of os.arch when running Java on the s390x platform?  Can someone get the properties from the s390x platform for us?

Can you run os.arch on your s390x system and let us know what value is returned and add it this bug? thanks!

(In reply to comment #6)

Tom Watson opened OSGi bug 436 to add this to the OSGi spec.

Based upon the results in comment 7, S390x has been defined by OSGi as the arch value. See http://www2.osgi.org/Specifications/Reference.
I'll release this next week, didn't have time this week.

>Hello Kim

I tried to run the source build  eclipse-sourceBuild-srcIncluded-I20070319-1800.zip (Mon, 19 Mar 2007 -- 18:00 (-0400)) s390x  with SLES9. I think i got late and could not find the build you had pointed to .To compile the source i had to do the following manipulations 

1)I got the error

So i removed -Xlint:none from jdtcoresrc/compilejdtcorewithjavac.xml
- <property name="compilerArg" value="-Xlint:none -encoding ISO-8859-1" />
+ <property name="compilerArg" value="-encoding ISO-8859-1" />

2)As once discussed before the plugins 
  org.eclipse.jdt.apt.pluggable.core,
  org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.apt,
  org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.apt
does not compile with the s390/s390x archs(gave errors:  requires source of the level 5.0) .I think because they Java 1.6, which is not supported in s390/s390x yet. i removed their compilation and assembly from 
  features/org.eclipse.jdt/build.xml
  features/org.eclipse.jdt/feature.xml
  assemble.org.eclipse.sdk.linux.gtk.S390x.xml
How do you think we would tackle this in the final version, do we have to remove that manually still if so what would be the proper place to document it.

3)On s390x to compile the X11 correctly libraries for swt i had to patch the file

plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.S390x/src/Eclipse SWT PI/gtk/library/build.sh

# For 64-bit CPUs, we have a switch
--if [ ${MODEL} = 'x86_64' -o ${MODEL} = 'ppc64' -o ${MODEL} = 'ia64' ]; then
++if [ ${MODEL} = 'x86_64' -o ${MODEL} = 'ppc64' -o ${MODEL} = 'ia64' -o ${MODEL} = 's390x' ]; then

Today's source build had a problem due to a new version of pde build that had unexpected consequences.  I have reverted to building with the previous version for the next build.

I assume the uname issue is a problem in the swt build scripts? Is this the case?
The reason that we name the fragments that way is to adhere to the OSGi naming convention for that platform. Do you have a workaround patch?

Hello Kim

1) I changed the META-INF/MANIFEST.MF:Eclipse-PlatformFilter: 
(& (osgi.ws=gtk) (osgi.os=linux) (osgi.arch=S390x)) to 
(& (osgi.ws=gtk) (osgi.os=linux) (osgi.arch=s390x) of the offending plugins and then recompiled.Eclipse failed to run chrashing the JVM just as above .

2)I have just raised a bug with the OSGi to either change or alias the arch name S390/S390x to s390/s390x 


Details of which are:


URL: https://www2.osgi.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=18


The bug no. is #18


Bug Type : OSGi Specifications


Bug Summary: Changing/creation of alias of arch name S390/S390x  to s390/s390x

The reason that the osgi value is S390/S390x is that S390 was an existing value.  See comment #7 in this bug.

I talked to the core team and it shouldn't matter what what the osgi value is as long as the arch value in the fragment's manifest and the feature match. 

What vm did you use to compile the source build?

Can you use gdb or something similar to look at the core file and try to determine where it failed?  I can't debug that from here.

How are you starting eclipse?

if so, can you trying invoking it this way to bypass the executable

java -jar plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.gtk.linux.s390x_1.0.0.v20070502.jar

I talked to Andrew and I think one the issues is that the org.eclipse.equinox.executable doesn't have a directory for this platform as the launcher does. So the executable that is bundled with your build is not appropriate for the platform.  This is request is in bug 186811.

Once this is created, I'll modify the build.properties the rcp, platform and sdk features, to point to the appropriate location for the executable to copy during the build.

You can replicate this now in your build by running 
features/org.eclipse.equinox.executable/library/gtk/build.sh

It should build the eclipse executable for your platform and also create a .so file that will be included in the org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.gtk.linux.S390x

Try this and see if we can get any further with the startup.

(In reply to comment #30)
> Talked to Andrew, he said that it there may need to be another flag when
> compiling the launcher. He'll look at the strace.
> 
The flag I was thinking of is DEFAULT_JAVA_EXEC, which causes the launcher to fork the vm by default instead of loading it in-process. See the build.sh script.  It looks like you are already compiling with this by looking at the sys_trace file.

It looks to me like the vm was started and then it returned with an exit code (line 585 in sys_trace):
wait4(-1, [{WIFEXITED(s) && WEXITSTATUS(s) == 160}], 0, NULL) = 30550
The rest of the sys_trace is the launcher attempting to show an error dialog.

In this case, look for a log file.  It may also be possible to debug the java by starting with "-vmargs -Xdebug -Xnoagent -Xrunjdwp:transport=dt_socket,address=8888,server=y,suspend=y" and then attaching with a java debugger.

Hello Kim

As Thomas Watson's mail say the s390/s390x name is case insensitive it would be good if the arch prefix could be changed to lower case s390/s390x to be consistent with everything else in System z?

Thank you

The Eclipse-PlatformFilter needs to use lower-case for s390/s390x.  The OSGi spec is not a good place to base casing on.  They just uppercase the first letter of every OS and Arch because casing does not matter in the OSGi defined matching (Bundle-NativeCode header).

The issues are occuring for the Eclipse-PlatformFilter.  This filter *is* case sensitive.  All Eclipse-PlatformFilter headers should be changed to lowercase s390/s390x.  It is likely the build system is setting the osgi.arch property to S390/S390x.  This will also have to change to build the bundles successfully.

For example, the bundle org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.S390x has the following header:

Eclipse-PlatformFilter: (& (osgi.ws=gtk) (osgi.os=linux) (osgi.arch=S390))

This should be changed to 

Eclipse-PlatformFilter: (& (osgi.ws=gtk) (osgi.os=linux) (osgi.arch=s390))
                                                                    ^
                                                              use lower-case

As mentioned in the last comment#27 point 4 the two small patches to be applied are
Note:- These diff patches are produced after replacing S390 with s390 in the whole source 
1)Filename to be applied :- "plugins/org.eclipse.swt/Eclipse SWT PI/gtk/library/build.sh"
--------patch----------------------------
--- build.sh.orig       2007-05-24 15:05:06.425578050 +0200
+++ build.sh    2007-05-25 09:46:44.975578050 +0200
@@ -65,7 +65,7 @@
 esac

 # For 64-bit CPUs, we have a switch
-if [ ${MODEL} = 'x86_64' -o ${MODEL} = 'ppc64' -o ${MODEL} = 'ia64' ]; then
+if [ ${MODEL} = 'x86_64' -o ${MODEL} = 'ppc64' -o ${MODEL} = 'ia64' -o ${MODEL} = 's390x' ]; then
        SWT_PTR_CFLAGS=-DSWT_PTR_SIZE_64
        export SWT_PTR_CFLAGS
        if [ -d /lib64 ]; then
------------------------------------

2)Filename to be applied:- "features/org.eclipse.equinox.executable/library/gtk/build.sh" also the same patch is applied to library/gtk/build.sh in side the ziped file "plugins/org.eclipse.platform/launchersrc.zip"
--------------patch------------------------------ 
--- build.sh.orig       2007-05-25 16:01:44.625578050 +0200
+++ build.sh    2007-05-25 16:12:45.685578050 +0200
@@ -67,6 +67,16 @@
                                defaultJava=DEFAULT_JAVA_EXEC
                                OUTPUT_DIR="../../bin/$defaultWS/$defaultOS/$defaultOSArch"
                                ;;
+                       "s390")
+                               defaultOSArch="s390"
+                               defaultJava=DEFAULT_JAVA_EXEC
+                               OUTPUT_DIR="../../bin/$defaultWS/$defaultOS/$defaultOSArch"
+                               ;;
+                       "s390x")
+                               defaultOSArch="s390x"
+                               defaultJava=DEFAULT_JAVA_EXEC
+                               OUTPUT_DIR="../../bin/$defaultWS/$defaultOS/$defaultOSArch"
+                               ;;
                        "ia64")
                                defaultOSArch="ia64"
                                defaultJava=DEFAULT_JAVA_EXEC

The source build creates a native filesystem lib but this fragment is not included in the feature because it isn't included in cvs.  This would break our build :-(

If you are interested in contributing this fragment, open a bug with eclipse core resources.  

In the interim, hack the platform feature to add the fragment and copy the fragment to the plugins dir

 <plugin
         id="org.eclipse.core.filesystem.linux.s390x"
         os="linux"
         arch="s390x"
         download-size="0"
         install-size="0"
         version="0.0.0"
         fragment="true"
         unpack="false"/>

Grant stopped by my office to discuss the libraries.  He suggested comparing with the libraries in the solaris.gtk.x86 build they include the same ones he mentioned. The mozilla, xul and xpcominit libraries will not be included unless you have the appropriate mozilla libraries to compile against.  Is there a version of mozilla available for this platform?  If not, eclipse will still start up.

To be specific on mozilla issue 
the swt make file only make the mozilla library by default if the mozilla support on the system is present.

The build files have to be tweaked in order to get compile xul and xpcominit libraries.I don't know the reason why it is so and I think it would be same for all platforms

To clarify (sorry if I'm repeating info that you already know):

- To build swt's mozilla library you need either a Mozilla/Gecko SDK or a Mozilla compiled from source; a Mozilla binary download is not adequate.  On Linux x86, SWT compiles its shipped mozilla library against a Mozilla 1.4 compiled from source with the following .mozconfig:

mk_add_options MOZ_OBJDIR=/bluebird/teamswt/swt-builddir/mozilla/1.4/linux_gtk2/mozilla
ac_add_options --disable-optimize
ac_add_options --disable-debug
ac_add_options --disable-profilelocking
ac_add_options --enable-default-toolkit=gtk2
ac_add_options --disable-freetype2
ac_add_options --enable-application=suite
mk_add_options MOZ_CO_PROJECT=suite

- To build swt's shipped xulrunner and xpcominit libraries on Linux x86 we compile against the xulrunner 1.8.0.4 SDK.  I think you'll have to compile xulrunner 1.8.0.4 from source on your machine, unless you're able to use one of the existing xulrunner 1.8.0.4 SDKs on the s390 (?).

- Now that I look, you're correct that only the mozilla library is compiled by default.  I was not aware of this because when we compile our libraries we have the MOZILLA_INCLUDES and MOZILLA_LIBS variables set, so we don't exercise the path in build.sh that you're seeing.  In case you're wondering, the mozilla-related variables that we set before compiling are:

setenv MOZILLA_SDK /bluebird/teamswt/swt-builddir/mozilla/1.4/linux_gtk2/mozilla/dist/sdk
setenv MOZILLA_INCLUDES "-include ${MOZILLA_SDK}/mozilla-config.h -I${MOZILLA_SDK}/../include/xpcom -I${MOZILLA_SDK}/../include/nspr -I${MOZILLA_SDK}/../include/embed_base -I${MOZILLA_SDK}/../include/embedstring -I${MOZILLA_SDK}/../include/string"
setenv MOZILLA_LIBS "${MOZILLA_SDK}/../lib/libembedstring.a -L${MOZILLA_SDK}/../bin -L${MOZILLA_SDK}/../lib/ -lxpcom -lnspr4 -lplds4 -lplc4"
setenv XULRUNNER_SDK /bluebird/teamswt/swt-builddir/geckoSDK/1.8.0.4/gecko-sdk
setenv XULRUNNER_INCLUDES "-include ${XULRUNNER_SDK}/include/mozilla-config.h -I${XULRUNNER_SDK}/include"
setenv XULRUNNER_LIBS "-L${XULRUNNER_SDK}/lib -lxpcomglue"

Thanks for the information
This is what i was able to do

i) With a mozilla-devel package for s390x/s390 (this provides all the development headers of Mozilla,xpcom etc..)I was able to compile to produce  
libswt-mozilla-gtk-3345.so sucessfully
The compile variables take the values automatically by pkg-config statement as:


MOZILLA_INCLUDES=-I/opt/mozilla/include -I/opt/mozilla/include/xpcom -I/opt/mozilla/include/string -I/opt/mozilla/include/nspr
MOZILLA_LIBS=-L/opt/mozilla/lib64 -L/opt/mozilla/lib -lxpcom -lplds4 -lplc4 -lnspr4 -lpthread -ldl


ii)With just the above package and the 2 addition to the file swt build.sh  

a) entries in the make command to make xulrunner and xpcominit libs

b)Setting  
XULRUNNER_INCLUDES=$MOZILLA_INCLUDES (as i saw both compile the same c file with different --args)

libswt-xulrunner-gtk-3345.so

To be clear about your mail 

You suggest that I open a bug  with product platform resources to begin 2 new filesystem fragments i.e
 org.eclipse.core.filesystem.linux.s390
 org.eclipse.core.filesystem.linux.s390x

Pardon my concern,but would it be ok to add new fragments at this stage of release
If no problem i'll imediately do it

My original patch contained contained these filesystem fragments but it was decided not to go with them in comment #4 and #5 :(

I think the xulrunner error you're getting is a result of using a mozilla sdk
instead of a xulrunner sdk.  GREVersionRange is used when dynamically detecting
a native browser at runtime, and this mechanism was only introduced as of
xulrunner, so I don't think it exists in the mozilla world.
(in the above comment I meant the xpcominit error, not xulrunner error)

Regarding comment #64, yes the filesystem fragments are optional.  If you want to open a request to add them, please do do.  I doubt that they will be included in the build at this stage of the release, at this point we are only fixing stop ship and documentation bugs.

In comment #59, I was just explaining why the filesystem fragment was being built by the source build, but not included in the final build.
